title: Ferdinand Lassalle
summary: Ferdinand Lassalle (German: [laˈsal]; 11 April 1825 – 31 August 1864) was a Prussian-German jurist, philosopher, socialist and political activist best remembered as the initiator of the social democratic movement in Germany.[1] "Lassalle was the first man in Germany, the first in Europe, who succeeded in organising a party of socialist action",[2] or, as Rosa Luxemburg put it: "Lassalle managed to wrestle from history in two years of flaming agitation what needed many decades to come about."[3] As agitator he coined the terms night-watchman state and iron law of wages.[4]
